definition: Largest merchants by annual card transaction volume. Organizations processing over 6 million Visa transactions per year or over 2.5 million Mastercard transactions per year. Typically large retailers, e-commerce platforms, multinational corporations, airlines, hospitality chains, and major service providers with extensive payment card operations.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Any merchant that has suffered a data breach or an attacker has compromised their account data, or any merchant processing over 6 million Visa transactions annually (across all channels) or over 2.5 million Mastercard transactions annually. Includes brick-and-mortar, e-commerce, mail/telephone order merchants.
transaction_threshold: Greater than 6 million Visa transactions/year OR Greater than 2.5 million Mastercard transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Quarterly network scans by ASV
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual QSA audit required; Quarterly external vulnerability scans by Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV); Annual penetration testing; Quarterly internal vulnerability scans; Network segmentation documentation; Incident response plan; Security awareness training program; Asset inventory; Firewall review
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1; ISO 27001 (recommended); SOC 2 Type II (recommended); GDPR (if EU operations); CCPA (if California operations); Payment Brand specific requirements (Visa, Mastercard, Amex, Discover, JCB)

definition: Mid-to-large size merchants processing between 1.5 million and 6 million Visa transactions annually or between 150,000 and 2.5 million Mastercard transactions annually. Includes regional retailers, medium e-commerce businesses, restaurant chains, healthcare providers, educational institutions, and growing enterprises.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Any merchant processing 1 million to 6 million Visa transactions annually or 150,000 to 2.5 million Mastercard transactions annually across all channels. Subject to mandatory annual assessments and reporting requirements similar to Level 1 merchants.
transaction_threshold: 1.5 million to 6 million Visa transactions/year OR 150,000 to 2.5 million Mastercard transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Quarterly network scans by ASV
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual QSA audit required; Quarterly external vulnerability scans by Approved Scanning Vendor (ASV); Annual penetration testing; Quarterly internal vulnerability scans; Network segmentation recommended; Incident response plan; Security awareness training; Vendor management program; Change control procedures
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1; ISO 27001 (recommended); SOC 2 (recommended); GDPR (if EU operations); CCPA (if California operations); Industry-specific regulations

definition: Small-to-medium size merchants processing between 20,000 and 1.5 million Visa e-commerce transactions annually or between 20,000 and 150,000 Mastercard e-commerce transactions annually. Includes small retailers, online businesses, professional services, non-profits, and emerging technology companies.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Any merchant processing 20,000 to 1 million Visa e-commerce transactions annually or 20,000 to 150,000 Mastercard e-commerce transactions annually. Self-assessment permitted with appropriate attestation and quarterly scanning requirements.
transaction_threshold: 20,000 to 1.5 million Visa e-commerce transactions/year OR 20,000 to 150,000 Mastercard e-commerce transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Quarterly network scans by ASV
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ A, A-EP, B, C, or D based on processing method); Attestation of Compliance signed by officer; Quarterly external vulnerability scans by ASV; Annual internal vulnerability scans; Security policies documented; Incident response procedures; Vendor security management; Training records maintained
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1; GDPR (if EU operations); CCPA (if California operations); Payment Brand requirements; Industry-specific standards as applicable

definition: Smallest merchants by transaction volume processing fewer than 20,000 Visa e-commerce transactions annually and all other merchants (regardless of acceptance channel) processing up to 1.5 million Visa transactions annually or up to 150,000 Mastercard transactions annually. Includes small businesses, sole proprietors, local shops, service providers, and micro-merchants.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Any merchant processing fewer than 20,000 Visa e-commerce transactions annually and all other merchants processing up to 1 million Visa transactions annually or up to 150,000 Mastercard transactions annually. May complete Self-Assessment Questionnaire with reduced validation requirements.
transaction_threshold: Fewer than 20,000 Visa e-commerce transactions/year AND up to 1.5 million Visa transactions/year (all channels) OR up to 150,000 Mastercard transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ); Compliance Validation may be required by Acquirer; Quarterly network scans by ASV (if applicable)
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements apply (validation methods vary); Annual Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ A, A-EP, B, C, or D); Compliance validation as required by acquiring bank; Quarterly scans for e-commerce merchants; Security policies appropriate to size; Basic security controls implemented; Payment application security; Third-party provider management
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1; GDPR (if applicable); Regional data protection laws; Payment Brand requirements; Acquirer-specific requirements

definition: Largest third-party service providers by transaction volume or criticality. Any service provider processing, storing, or transmitting over 300,000 Visa transactions annually or designated by payment brands as Level 1 due to criticality. Includes major payment processors, payment gateways, hosting providers, cloud service providers, managed security providers, and technology vendors serving merchants.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Any third-party entity that is not a payment brand and is directly involved in the processing, storage, or transmission of cardholder data. Level 1 Service Providers process, store, or transmit over 300,000 Visa transactions annually OR have suffered a breach OR are deemed critical by payment brands. Must register with payment brands.
transaction_threshold: Greater than 300,000 Visa transactions/year OR deemed critical by payment brands
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance (AOC) submitted to payment brands; Quarterly network scans by ASV
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual QSA audit required; Report on Compliance submitted to all applicable payment brands; Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly external vulnerability scans by ASV; Annual penetration testing; Quarterly internal vulnerability scans; Comprehensive security program; Incident response and breach notification; Service provider registration with Visa/Mastercard; Vendor risk management; Multi-tenant security controls
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PTS (if applicable); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; GDPR (if EU operations); CCPA (if California); Cloud Security Alliance (CSA); Industry-specific compliance (HIPAA for healthcare, etc.)

definition: Mid-size third-party service providers processing or handling fewer than 300,000 Visa transactions annually. Includes regional payment processors, smaller payment gateways, IT service providers, software vendors, SaaS platforms, telecommunications providers, and consultancies supporting payment environments.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Any service provider processing, storing, or transmitting fewer than 300,000 Visa transactions annually. May complete Self-Assessment Questionnaire instead of QSA audit subject to payment brand and acquirer requirements. Must maintain compliance program and documentation.
transaction_threshold: Fewer than 300,000 Visa transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ D for Service Providers); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Quarterly network scans by ASV; Additional validation may be required by clients or payment brands
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual Self-Assessment Questionnaire (SAQ D-Service Provider); Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly external vulnerability scans by ASV; Annual penetration testing; Quarterly internal vulnerability scans; Security policies and procedures; Third-party vendor assessment; Client security responsibility matrix; Service provider agreement templates; Annual review and update
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); ISO 27001 (recommended); SOC 2 Type II (recommended); GDPR (if applicable); CCPA (if applicable); Cloud security standards; Industry-specific regulations

definition: Organizations that facilitate payment transactions between merchants and payment networks. Responsibilities include transaction authorization, clearing, settlement, encryption/decryption of payment data, fraud detection, and compliance monitoring. Includes front-end processors, back-end processors, and integrated payment service providers.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Member or organization that processes payment card transactions on behalf of merchants and connects to payment networks for authorization and settlement. Processors handle large volumes of sensitive authentication data and cardholder data. Subject to stringent security requirements and oversight by payment brands and card networks.
transaction_threshold: Processes millions to billions of transactions annually for multiple merchants
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Quarterly network scans; Continuous monitoring; Payment brand audits
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual QSA comprehensive audit; Payment brand security assessments; Network security controls; HSM (Hardware Security Module) management; Encryption key management; Multi-factor authentication; Segregation of duties; 24/7 security operations center; Real-time fraud monitoring; Incident response; Business continuity; Disaster recovery; Vendor management; Compliance reporting to payment brands; Annual penetration testing; Quarterly vulnerability scans (internal and external)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PTS (Payment Application security); PCI PIN (for PIN processing); ISO 27001; SOC 1 Type II; SOC 2 Type II; GDPR (global operations); Regional data protection laws; Banking regulations; Payment network operating rules (Visa, Mastercard, etc.); FFIEC guidance (US)

definition: Financial institutions that establish and maintain relationships with merchants to enable them to accept payment cards. Responsibilities include merchant underwriting, PCI DSS compliance enforcement, transaction processing contracts, dispute resolution, and regulatory compliance. Subject to payment brand requirements and banking regulations.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Member financial institution or bank that processes payment card transactions for merchants and maintains merchant relationships. Acquirers are responsible for ensuring merchant compliance with PCI DSS, enforcing security requirements, validating merchant compliance levels, and reporting to payment brands. Subject to payment brand audits and regulatory oversight.
transaction_threshold: Manages thousands to millions of merchant accounts processing billions in transaction volume
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance; Payment brand compliance validation; Regulatory examinations; Quarterly scans
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory for acquirer infrastructure; Annual QSA audit; Payment brand security programs; Merchant compliance monitoring program; Merchant onboarding security validation; Risk-based merchant compliance level assignment; Quarterly merchant scan validation; Compromise investigation procedures; Regulatory compliance (banking regulations); Anti-money laundering (AML) programs; Know Your Customer (KYC); Fraud monitoring; Merchant agreement security clauses; Penalty enforcement; Incident response; Business continuity
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); ISO 27001; SOC 1 Type II; SOC 2 Type II; GDPR (if applicable); Banking regulations (Basel III, Dodd-Frank, etc.); Anti-Money Laundering (AML); Know Your Customer (KYC); OFAC compliance; Payment brand operating rules; Regional banking regulations; Financial services sector-specific standards

definition: Financial institutions that issue payment cards to cardholders and maintain cardholder accounts. Responsibilities include card issuance, cardholder authentication, transaction authorization decisions, fraud management, account management, and cardholder data protection. Subject to payment brand and banking regulations.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Member financial institution or bank that issues payment cards to cardholders. Issuers are responsible for cardholder authentication, authorization of transactions, account management, and protection of cardholder data including Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD). Must comply with PCI DSS for systems storing, processing, or transmitting cardholder data. Subject to payment brand oversight.
transaction_threshold: Issues millions of payment cards; processes billions in authorization requests
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance; Payment brand audits; Regulatory examinations; Continuous monitoring
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual QSA audit for issuer processing systems; Payment brand security requirements; Cardholder authentication systems (EMV, 3D Secure); Fraud detection and prevention; Account management security; Sensitive Authentication Data (SAD) handling (must NOT store post-authorization); Cryptographic key management; HSM deployment; Multi-factor authentication; Mobile banking security; Online banking security; Call center security; Card production security; PIN management; Regulatory compliance; Incident response; Breach notification; Business continuity
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PCI PIN (for PIN-based cards); EMV specifications; 3-D Secure; ISO 27001; SOC 1 Type II; SOC 2 Type II; GDPR; Banking regulations; Consumer protection laws; Anti-Money Laundering (AML); Know Your Customer (KYC); Regional financial services regulations; Payment brand operating rules (Visa Core Rules, Mastercard Standards)

definition: Technology service providers that facilitate online payment processing by securely transmitting transaction data between merchants (e-commerce sites) and payment processors or acquiring banks. Includes hosted payment pages, API-based gateways, and integrated payment solutions for web and mobile applications.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider that provides payment gateway services connecting merchant websites/applications to payment processors. Gateways transmit and may temporarily store cardholder data. Critical service provider requiring comprehensive security controls including network security, encryption, tokenization, fraud detection, and secure APIs.
transaction_threshold: Varies by transaction volume processed; typically Level 1 if processing over 300,000 transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA (Level 1) or SAQ D-Service Provider (Level 2); Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly ASV scans
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; Network segmentation; TLS 1.2+ encryption; Tokenization services; Hosted payment page security; API security; PCI DSS scoping; Multi-tenant environment security; Fraud detection; Transaction monitoring; Developer security training; Secure coding practices; Penetration testing; Vulnerability management; Incident response; 24/7 monitoring; Uptime/availability SLAs; Data breach insurance; Quarterly scans; Annual penetration testing
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS (if applicable); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; GDPR; CCPA; Cloud security standards; API security standards (OAuth, OpenID); Web application security (OWASP); Payment brand requirements

definition: Cloud infrastructure, platform, or software service providers that host, store, or process cardholder data on behalf of merchants or service providers. Includes Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS), Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS), and Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) providers supporting payment applications or cardholder data environments.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider offering cloud computing services (IaaS, PaaS, SaaS) that stores, processes, or transmits cardholder data or provides infrastructure for cardholder data environments. Responsible for infrastructure security, network segmentation, encryption, access controls, and shared responsibility model documentation. Must maintain PCI DSS compliance for services in scope.
transaction_threshold: Varies by volume; Level 1 if critical or high transaction volume
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment (Level 1) or SAQ D-Service Provider (Level 2); Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly scans; Third-party audit reports (SOC 2)
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements for in-scope systems; Shared responsibility matrix clearly defined; Infrastructure security controls; Network virtualization security; Multi-tenancy controls; Container security; Encryption at rest and in transit; Key management; Access control and identity management; Logging and monitoring; Backup and recovery; Physical data center security; Compliance inheritance documentation; Customer responsibility documentation; Security configuration baselines; Vulnerability scanning; Penetration testing; Incident response; Breach notification; Service provider registration
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; CSA STAR Certification; GDPR; HIPAA (if applicable); FedRAMP (for government clients); Regional data sovereignty laws; Cloud security frameworks; Payment brand requirements

definition: Organizations providing managed security services for entities handling cardholder data. Services include managed firewall, intrusion detection/prevention, SIEM monitoring, vulnerability scanning, log management, incident response, and security operations center (SOC) services for payment environments.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider offering managed security services that monitor, manage, or have access to cardholder data environments or security controls protecting cardholder data. MSSPs must maintain PCI DSS compliance for their infrastructure and demonstrate secure practices for accessing client environments. Responsible for security control effectiveness and monitoring.
transaction_threshold: Varies; typically Level 1 if managing critical infrastructure for Level 1 entities
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment or SAQ D-Service Provider; Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly ASV scans; Client audit rights
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements for MSSP infrastructure; Secure remote access (MFA required); Network segmentation between clients; Least privilege access; Monitoring and logging of administrative access; Incident response procedures; Security operations center (SOC) security; SIEM platform security; Vulnerability management; Threat intelligence; Client data segregation; Secure communication channels; Personnel background checks; Security awareness training; Non-disclosure agreements; Service level agreements; Right-to-audit clauses; Third-party risk management; Annual security assessments
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; ISO 27017 (cloud security); ISO 27018 (cloud privacy); GDPR; Regional data protection laws; NIST Cybersecurity Framework; Industry-specific standards

definition: Merchants conducting business primarily or exclusively through online channels where payment cards are not physically present. Includes online retailers, subscription services, digital goods providers, software-as-a-service (SaaS) vendors, and marketplace platforms. Higher fraud risk due to card-not-present transactions.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Merchant that accepts payment cards through e-commerce channels (websites, mobile apps, APIs) where the cardholder and payment card are not physically present at the point of sale. Subject to all PCI DSS requirements with specific focus on web application security, transmission security, tokenization, fraud prevention, and secure payment pages. Compliance level varies by transaction volume.
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual e-commerce transaction volume (see Level 1-4 thresholds)
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Typically SAQ A or A-EP for hosted payment pages, SAQ D for direct processing
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; Web application firewall (WAF); Secure coding practices; Input validation; Output encoding; SQL injection prevention; Cross-site scripting (XSS) prevention; Authentication and session management; TLS 1.2+ for all transmission; Tokenization (recommended); Hosted payment page (recommended); PCI DSS SAQ A or A-EP scoping; fraud detection; 3D Secure authentication; Address Verification Service (AVS); Card Verification Value (CVV) validation; Velocity checks; IP geolocation; Device fingerprinting; Security awareness training; Quarterly ASV scans; Annual penetration testing
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS (for payment applications); OWASP Top 10; Web application security standards; GDPR (if EU customers); CCPA (if California customers); Consumer protection laws; E-commerce platform security; Payment gateway security; Regional data protection laws

definition: Merchants conducting business in physical locations where payment cards are physically presented for transactions. Includes brick-and-mortar stores, restaurants, gas stations, hotels, and face-to-face service providers. Uses point-of-sale (POS) terminals, card readers, and EMV chip card technology.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Merchant accepting payment cards through face-to-face channels where the cardholder presents the physical card at point-of-sale. Includes magnetic stripe swipe, EMV chip card insertion, and contactless/NFC payments. Subject to all PCI DSS requirements with focus on physical security, POS security, and card reader protection. Compliance level varies by transaction volume.
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume across all channels (see Level 1-4 thresholds)
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Typically SAQ B or C for EMV terminals, SAQ D for integrated systems
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; Secure POS terminals; EMV chip card acceptance; P2PE (Point-to-Point Encryption) recommended; Physical security of POS devices; Tamper-evident seals; POS terminal inspection procedures; Network segmentation (isolate payment network); Secure remote access to POS; POS software security patches; Anti-malware on POS systems; Contactless payment security; Mobile POS security; Card reader security; Receipt security (mask PAN); Employee training on card handling; Physical access controls to back-office; Video surveillance; SAQ validation; Quarterly scans; Penetration testing (Level 1-2)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PTS for POS applications; P2PE standards (if applicable); EMV specifications; ISO 27001 (optional); Regional retail security standards; Consumer protection laws; Labor regulations; Payment brand requirements

definition: Merchants accepting payment cards through multiple channels including physical stores, e-commerce websites, mobile applications, call centers (mail order/telephone order), and social commerce. Complex compliance requirements due to multiple payment acceptance methods and integrated customer data across channels.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Merchant processing payment card transactions through multiple acceptance channels (in-store, online, mobile, phone, etc.) requiring comprehensive security controls across all environments. Must scope all channels, implement consistent security controls, and coordinate compliance across different processing methods. Compliance level typically Level 1 or 2 due to volume and complexity.
transaction_threshold: Varies; typically high volume due to multiple channels; Often exceeds 6 million transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment (typically required due to complexity); Report on Compliance covering all channels; Quarterly ASV scans; Annual penetration testing; SAQ may be possible for smaller omnichannel merchants
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements across all channels; Network segmentation per channel; E-commerce security (TLS, WAF, secure coding); POS security (EMV, P2PE); Call center security (prohibit recording CVV, secure IVR); Mobile app security; API security; Tokenization across channels; Centralized logging and monitoring; Unified incident response; Cross-channel fraud detection; Consistent access controls; Employee training for all channels; Third-party vendor management; Compliance program management; Comprehensive security policies; Quarterly scans for all external IPs; Annual penetration testing (all channels); Network diagrams documenting all environments; Data flow diagrams; Cardholder data inventory
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PTS; P2PE; ISO 27001 (recommended); SOC 2 (if SaaS components); GDPR; CCPA; Consumer protection laws; Channel-specific regulations; E-commerce platform security; POS security; Payment brand requirements; Industry-specific standards

definition: Third-party service providers that enable sub-merchants (often small businesses) to accept payment cards without establishing their own direct merchant accounts. PayFacs assume liability and compliance responsibility for sub-merchants, performing underwriting, onboarding, and compliance monitoring. Also called aggregators or master merchants.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider that facilitates payment card acceptance for multiple sub-merchants under a master merchant account. PayFacs are responsible for sub-merchant compliance with PCI DSS, must maintain their own compliance, validate sub-merchant security, and report to payment brands. Subject to enhanced oversight due to sub-merchant liability.
transaction_threshold: Aggregates transactions for potentially thousands of sub-merchants; typically processes over 300,000 transactions annually
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Quarterly ASV scans; Payment brand registration and ongoing reporting
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements for PayFac infrastructure; Sub-merchant onboarding security validation; Risk-based sub-merchant compliance monitoring; Sub-merchant compliance level assignment; Attestation of sub-merchant compliance; Sub-merchant SAQ validation; Quarterly scan coordination for sub-merchants; Incident response for sub-merchant breaches; Sub-merchant agreement security clauses; Fraud monitoring across sub-merchant portfolio; Know Your Customer (KYC) for sub-merchants; Reserve account management; Chargeback management; Regulatory compliance (money transmitter licenses); Payment brand registration; Payment brand reporting; Penalty management for sub-merchant non-compliance
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; Payment brand operating rules; Money transmitter regulations; Anti-Money Laundering (AML); Know Your Customer (KYC); GDPR; CCPA; Regional payment facilitator regulations; Payment gateway security standards

definition: Software developers and vendors that create payment applications, point-of-sale software, shopping carts, payment modules, mobile payment apps, or other software that processes, stores, or transmits cardholder data. ISVs must ensure applications are developed securely and validated against PA-DSS or PCI SSC standards.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Third-party software vendor developing payment applications used by merchants or service providers to process, store, or transmit cardholder data. ISVs are responsible for secure software development lifecycle, security testing, vulnerability remediation, and ongoing security support. Applications may require PA-DSS validation or adherence to PCI Secure Software Standard.
transaction_threshold: Varies by deployment scale; Level 1 if software widely deployed or processing for Level 1 merchants
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment or SAQ D-Service Provider; PA-DSS validation (if applicable); Attestation of Compliance; Security testing results
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements for development environment and infrastructure; Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC); Threat modeling; Secure coding standards (OWASP); Code review (manual and automated); Static Application Security Testing (SAST); Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST); Penetration testing; Vulnerability remediation; PA-DSS validation (if storing, processing, or transmitting CHD); PCI Secure Software Standard compliance; Software composition analysis (third-party libraries); Security patch management; Customer security guidance; Application hardening documentation; Secure default configurations; Customer implementation validation; Developer security training
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PCI Secure Software Standard; ISO 27001; OWASP; Secure coding standards; GDPR; CCPA; Software supply chain security; DevSecOps frameworks; Application security standards; Payment brand requirements

definition: Any external organization providing services that impact the security of cardholder data environments but may not directly process cardholder data. Includes IT consulting firms, system integrators, network engineers, database administrators, auditors, and support providers with access to systems or networks containing cardholder data.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider that has access to, or could impact the security of, cardholder data or the cardholder data environment but does not store, process, or transmit cardholder data as part of service delivery. TPSPs must maintain security controls appropriate to their access level and scope of services. Subject to PCI DSS requirements for systems they manage or access.
transaction_threshold: Not determined by transaction volume; based on scope of access and criticality
assessment_type: SAQ D-Service Provider; Attestation of Compliance; May require QSA audit based on client requirements or scope
compliance_requirements: PCI DSS requirements based on scope of services provided; Secure remote access (VPN with MFA); Least privilege access; Access control management; Authentication requirements; Activity logging and monitoring; Background checks for personnel; Non-disclosure agreements; Security awareness training; Incident response coordination; Vulnerability management for systems accessed; Secure disposal of client data; Service level agreements with security clauses; Right-to-audit provisions; Third-party risk assessments; Insurance (E&O, cyber liability); Compliance monitoring and reporting; Quarterly reviews of access; Annual compliance validation
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory for scope); ISO 27001 (recommended); SOC 2 Type II (recommended); GDPR (if applicable); Industry-specific regulations; Professional standards (consulting); Regional data protection laws; Payment brand requirements; Client-specific security requirements

definition: Service providers offering mobile payment solutions including mobile wallets, person-to-person (P2P) payment apps, in-app payment processing, mobile point-of-sale (mPOS) solutions, contactless payment services (NFC), and QR code payment systems. Handles payment data on mobile devices.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider offering payment acceptance through mobile devices (smartphones, tablets) or mobile applications. Includes mobile wallet providers, mPOS vendors, and in-app payment processors. Responsible for mobile application security, device security, secure data storage on mobile devices, and protection of cardholder data in mobile environments. Subject to PCI Mobile Payment Acceptance Security Guidelines.
transaction_threshold: Varies by transaction volume and deployment scale; Level 1 if exceeding 300,000 transactions/year
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment (Level 1) or SAQ D-Service Provider (Level 2); Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly ASV scans; Mobile application security testing
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; PCI Mobile Payment Guidelines compliance; Mobile application security testing; Secure coding for mobile apps; Encryption of data at rest on mobile devices; Secure data transmission (TLS 1.2+); Mobile device security (jailbreak/root detection); Biometric authentication support; Tokenization (recommended); EMV/NFC security (contactless payments); Bluetooth security (card readers); Mobile SDK security; API security; Multi-factor authentication; Device attestation; Remote wipe capabilities; Secure key storage (Keychain/Keystore); Certificate pinning; Obfuscation; App store security review; Penetration testing; Quarterly vulnerability scanning; Incident response
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PCI Mobile Payment Acceptance Guidelines; PA-DSS (if applicable); EMV specifications; ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; GDPR; CCPA; Mobile platform security guidelines (Apple, Google); OWASP Mobile Top 10; Payment brand requirements; Regional mobile payment regulations

definition: Telecommunications companies providing network connectivity, voice services, or infrastructure supporting payment card transactions. Includes internet service providers (ISPs), telecom carriers, network service providers, and companies offering point-of-sale dial-up or broadband connectivity for payment processing.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Service provider offering telecommunications or network services used to transmit cardholder data between merchants, processors, and payment networks. Responsible for network security, transmission encryption, access controls, and protection of cardholder data in transit. Scope limited to network segments handling payment data.
transaction_threshold: Varies by scope; Level 1 if providing critical network infrastructure for payment processing
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment or SAQ D-Service Provider based on volume and criticality; Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly ASV scans
compliance_requirements: PCI DSS requirements applicable to network infrastructure in scope; Network segmentation; Encryption of cardholder data in transit (TLS 1.2+); Network access controls; Firewall configurations; Intrusion detection/prevention systems; Network monitoring and logging; Physical security of network infrastructure; Secure remote access (MFA); Change control for network configurations; Vendor management (hardware, software); Vulnerability management; Penetration testing of network infrastructure; Incident response; Business continuity; Disaster recovery; DDoS protection; Network availability SLAs; Documentation of network architecture
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (scope-dependent); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; Telecommunications regulations (FCC, regional telecom authorities); Network security standards; GDPR; Regional data protection laws; Payment brand requirements

definition: Cloud-based software providers offering applications that process, store, or transmit cardholder data. Includes subscription management platforms, billing systems, customer relationship management (CRM) systems with payment processing, accounting software with payment features, and vertical-specific SaaS platforms (e.g., restaurant, retail, healthcare).
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: SaaS provider offering cloud-based applications that handle cardholder data on behalf of customers. Responsible for application security, infrastructure security, multi-tenant security, data isolation, secure APIs, and shared responsibility model. Customers and SaaS provider share PCI DSS compliance responsibilities based on service delivery model.
transaction_threshold: Varies by transaction volume and customer base; Level 1 if exceeding 300,000 transactions/year or serving Level 1 merchants
assessment_type: Annual QSA Assessment (Level 1) or SAQ D-Service Provider (Level 2); Attestation of Compliance; Quarterly ASV scans; SOC 2 Type II audit recommended
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements for SaaS infrastructure and application; Multi-tenant security controls; Data segregation between customers; Role-based access control; API security (authentication, authorization, rate limiting); Secure software development lifecycle; Web application firewall (WAF); Database security; Encryption at rest and in transit; Tokenization (if applicable); Secure configuration management; Patch management; Vulnerability scanning; Penetration testing; Logging and monitoring; Incident response; Shared responsibility matrix documentation; Customer compliance guidance; Customer security settings; Backup and recovery; Business continuity; Disaster recovery; Service level agreements (SLAs)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PCI Secure Software Standard (if applicable); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II (highly recommended); CSA STAR; GDPR; CCPA; HIPAA (if healthcare); Industry-specific regulations; Cloud security frameworks; OWASP; Secure coding standards; Payment brand requirements

definition: Organizations that provide back-end processing services for acquiring banks, handling transaction authorization routing, clearing, settlement, and reporting. Connects acquiring banks to payment networks and card issuers. Critical infrastructure requiring highest security controls and 24/7 operations.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Processor providing transaction processing services connecting acquiring banks to payment card networks (Visa, Mastercard, etc.). Handles transaction authorization requests, clearing files, settlement processing, and reporting. Processes large volumes of sensitive payment data requiring comprehensive security controls, network security, encryption, access controls, and operational resilience.
transaction_threshold: Processes millions to billions of transactions annually for multiple acquiring banks and thousands of merchants
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA; Report on Compliance (RoC); Attestation of Compliance (AOC); Payment brand security assessments; Quarterly ASV scans; Continuous monitoring
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements mandatory; Annual QSA comprehensive audit; Payment network security requirements; Hardware Security Module (HSM) management; Cryptographic key management; Network security controls (firewalls, IDS/IPS); Secure authorization routing; Clearing and settlement security; Multi-factor authentication; Privileged access management; Segregation of duties; 24/7 security operations center (SOC); Real-time transaction monitoring; Fraud detection systems; Incident response; Business continuity; Disaster recovery; Redundancy and failover; Compliance reporting to payment brands; Quarterly vulnerability scans; Annual penetration testing; Third-party vendor management
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PCI PIN (if PIN processing); ISO 27001; SOC 1 Type II; SOC 2 Type II; Payment network operating rules (VisaNet, Mastercard Banknet); Regional financial regulations; Banking regulations; GDPR; Regional data protection laws; FFIEC guidance (US)

definition: Merchants accepting payment card transactions where the card is not physically presented, specifically through mail order or telephone (phone) order channels. Includes catalog retailers, call centers, telemarketing, subscription services, and businesses processing orders via written forms or phone. Higher fraud risk compared to card-present transactions.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Merchant accepting payment cards via mail or telephone where the cardholder provides card information remotely without physical card presentation. Subject to all PCI DSS requirements with specific focus on call center security, secure handling of written orders, prohibition on recording full PAN or CVV, Interactive Voice Response (IVR) security, and employee training on secure card data handling.
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume across all channels (see Level 1-4 thresholds)
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Typically SAQ C-VT for phone/mail order processing
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; Call center security controls; Prohibition on recording cardholder data (audio recordings must not capture PAN or CVV); Dual-Tone Multi-Frequency (DTMF) masking; Interactive Voice Response (IVR) security; Secure storage of written orders; PAN masking on paper forms; Physical security for mail order forms; Shredding/secure disposal of documents containing CHD; Employee training on PCI DSS; Access controls to cardholder data; Screen masking during data entry; Secure transmission to payment processor (TLS 1.2+); Fraud prevention (AVS, CVV validation); Monitoring and logging of access; Security awareness for call center staff; Quarterly ASV scans; Penetration testing (Level 1-2)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS (for payment applications); Telemarketing regulations; Consumer protection laws; Do Not Call regulations; GDPR (if EU customers); CCPA (if California customers); Telephone Consumer Protection Act (US); Call center security standards; Payment brand requirements

definition: Merchants that store cardholder data for recurring billing purposes. Includes subscription services (streaming, software-as-a-service, membership organizations), utilities, insurance companies, recurring donation platforms, and any business model charging customers on a recurring schedule (monthly, annually, etc.).
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Merchant storing cardholder data (Primary Account Number) for future recurring transactions. Higher PCI DSS requirements due to data storage. Must encrypt stored PAN, implement strict access controls, and maintain comprehensive security program. Subject to enhanced scrutiny and higher compliance requirements compared to merchants not storing cardholder data.
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume (see Level 1-4 thresholds); Often Level 2-3 due to business model
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Typically SAQ D due to cardholder data storage
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements with emphasis on data protection; Strong encryption of stored PAN (AES-256 or equivalent); Secure cryptographic key management; Strict access controls to stored cardholder data; Tokenization highly recommended (reduces PCI scope); Data retention policy (delete data when no longer needed); Quarterly data inventory and validation; Audit logging of all access to cardholder data; Multi-factor authentication for access; Role-based access control; Secure deletion procedures; Recurring billing authorization management; Card expiration date monitoring and updating; Account updater services; Fraud monitoring; Quarterly ASV scans; Annual penetration testing; Data backup security; Incident response plan
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS (for billing applications); ISO 27001 (recommended); GDPR (right to deletion, data minimization); CCPA; Consumer protection laws; Subscription billing regulations; Auto-renewal disclosure laws; Regional data protection laws; Payment brand requirements

definition: Merchants in hospitality industry including hotels, resorts, restaurants, bars, catering services, food delivery platforms, and entertainment venues. Often process high volumes of card-present and card-not-present transactions with unique PCI DSS challenges including property management systems (PMS), point-of-sale systems, advance reservations, and authorization holds.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Hospitality merchant accepting payment cards for lodging, food service, or entertainment. Subject to all PCI DSS requirements with specific considerations for property management systems, restaurant POS systems, reservations systems, gift card programs, and integration challenges between multiple systems. Compliance level based on annual transaction volume.
compliance_level: Varies (Level 1-4 based on transaction volume); Large chains typically Level 1-2
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume across all properties and channels
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Often SAQ D due to complex integrated systems
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; Property Management System (PMS) security; Point-of-sale (POS) security for restaurants/bars; Reservation system security; Authorization hold management; Integration security (PMS-POS-reservations); Network segmentation (isolate payment systems); EMV chip card acceptance; Contactless payment support; Mobile payment acceptance; Online booking security (if applicable); Call center security (reservations); Employee training (front desk, servers, bartenders); Physical security of payment terminals; Gift card program security (if in scope); Third-party integration security (travel sites, delivery platforms); Wireless network security; Video surveillance; Quarterly ASV scans; Penetration testing (Level 1-2)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); PA-DSS/PTS (POS/PMS applications); P2PE (recommended); GDPR (if EU guests); CCPA (if California); Hospitality industry standards; Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) compliance; Health department regulations (restaurants); Payment brand requirements; State/local hospitality regulations

definition: Healthcare organizations accepting payment cards for patient payments, co-pays, deductibles, and medical services. Includes hospitals, medical practices, dental offices, pharmacies, medical laboratories, and healthcare service providers. Subject to both PCI DSS and HIPAA requirements creating complex compliance environment.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Healthcare entity accepting payment cards for medical services or products. Must comply with PCI DSS for payment card data protection AND HIPAA for protected health information (PHI). Requires careful segregation of cardholder data and health information, separate security controls, and coordination between PCI DSS and HIPAA compliance programs. Compliance level based on transaction volume.
compliance_level: Varies (Level 1-4 based on transaction volume); Most healthcare providers Level 3-4
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual card transaction volume (see Level 1-4 thresholds)
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); SAQ type depends on payment processing method
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; Clear segregation of PCI and HIPAA data; Separate security controls for CHD vs PHI; Point-of-sale security (reception desks); Online payment portal security; Payment plan management; Billing system security; Practice management system scoping; Electronic Health Record (EHR) scoping; Insurance claim processing (typically out of PCI scope if no CHD stored); Patient payment plans; Tokenization recommended; Role-based access control; Staff training (PCI DSS and HIPAA); Physical security; Quarterly ASV scans; Penetration testing (Level 1-2); Business associate agreements with payment processors; Incident response (coordinate PCI and HIPAA breach notification)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); HIPAA Security Rule (mandatory); HIPAA Privacy Rule; HITECH Act; ISO 27001 (recommended); State healthcare privacy laws; Healthcare industry security frameworks; GDPR (if EU patients); CCPA (if California); Payment brand requirements; CMS regulations; Healthcare accreditation standards

definition: Schools, colleges, universities, and other educational institutions accepting payment cards for tuition, fees, bookstore purchases, dining services, parking, and other campus services. Often process large volumes during registration periods with complex payment scenarios including payment plans, financial aid coordination, and multi-departmental card acceptance.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Educational institution accepting payment cards for institutional services, tuition, fees, or products. Subject to all PCI DSS requirements with considerations for multiple payment acceptance points (admissions, bursar, bookstore, dining, athletics, parking), student information system integration, payment plan management, and large seasonal transaction volumes. Compliance level typically Level 2-3 for large universities.
compliance_level: Varies (Level 1-4 based on transaction volume); Large universities often Level 1-2
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume across all campus departments
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Often requires comprehensive assessment due to distributed payment acceptance
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements across all departments; Centralized payment security policy; Decentralized payment acceptance point security; Student information system (SIS) scoping; Bursar office security; Bookstore POS security; Dining services payment systems; Athletic ticket sales; Parking payment systems; Online payment portals; Payment plan management; Network segmentation; Departmental security responsibility matrix; Faculty/staff training; Student worker training; Third-party vendor management (payment processors); Campus-wide network security; Wireless network security; Physical security; Quarterly ASV scans; Penetration testing; Incident response coordination; Payment Card Acceptance Policy
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); FERPA (student privacy); GDPR (if EU students); State education privacy laws; Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (if offering financial services); Payment brand requirements; Educational institution security standards; Campus security policies; Regional education regulations

definition: Non-profit organizations, charities, foundations, religious organizations, and NGOs accepting payment card donations, membership fees, event registrations, or fundraising contributions. Often have limited IT resources and security expertise creating compliance challenges. Subject to full PCI DSS requirements regardless of non-profit status.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Non-profit organization accepting payment cards for donations, memberships, event registrations, or other contributions. Subject to identical PCI DSS requirements as for-profit merchants with compliance level determined by transaction volume. Often face compliance challenges due to limited budgets, volunteer staff, and resource constraints. No exemptions from PCI DSS based on non-profit status.
compliance_level: Varies (Level 1-4 based on transaction volume); Most non-profits Level 3-4
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume (see Level 1-4 thresholds)
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Most complete SAQ A, A-EP, or C depending on processing method
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements (no non-profit exemptions); Donation page security (if accepting online donations); Payment processor selection (consider hosted solutions to reduce scope); Recurring donation management; Event registration security; Membership management system security; Volunteer access controls; Outsourcing security functions (cost-effective approach); Third-party fundraising platform security; Payment terminal security; Donor data protection; Tokenization recommended; Training for staff and volunteers; Written security policies; Quarterly ASV scans; Incident response; Budget allocation for security; Grant funding for compliance; Third-party compliance services
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); GDPR (if EU donors); CCPA (if California); Charitable solicitation regulations; State non-profit regulations; IRS regulations (tax-deductible donations); Non-profit governance standards; Payment brand requirements; Regional data protection laws; Fundraising regulations

definition: Federal, state, local, or international government entities accepting payment cards for taxes, fees, fines, permits, licenses, utility payments, or government services. Subject to PCI DSS plus additional government security requirements (NIST, FedRAMP, FISMA). Often process high volumes with sensitive citizen data requiring enhanced security controls.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Government entity accepting payment cards for government services, taxes, fees, or fines. Subject to all PCI DSS requirements PLUS additional government security frameworks (FISMA, NIST, FedRAMP, etc.). Must coordinate PCI DSS compliance with government IT security requirements creating complex compliance environment. Compliance level based on transaction volume; large agencies often Level 1-2.
compliance_level: Varies (Level 1-4 based on transaction volume); Large agencies often Level 1-2
transaction_threshold: Compliance level determined by annual transaction volume (see Level 1-4 thresholds)
assessment_type: Varies by level: QSA audit (Level 1-2) or SAQ (Level 3-4); Often requires QSA due to complexity and government requirements
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements; NIST Cybersecurity Framework (US federal); FISMA compliance (US federal); FedRAMP authorization (for cloud services); Federal/state/local government security policies; Tax payment system security; Permit and licensing system security; Fine and fee collection security; Utility payment security; Online citizen portal security; Call center security (phone payments); Kiosk security (self-service payment terminals); Network security (government networks); Access controls (government personnel clearances); Physical security (government facilities); Encryption (FIPS 140-2 compliant); Logging and monitoring; Incident response (coordinate with CISO/CIO); Quarterly ASV scans; Penetration testing; Authority To Operate (ATO) process; Continuous monitoring; Vendor security assessment (government procurement)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); FISMA (US federal); NIST SP 800-53 (US federal); FedRAMP (US federal cloud); FIPS 140-2 (encryption); State/local government security standards; GDPR (if applicable); International government security frameworks; Payment brand requirements; Government audit requirements; Treasury regulations (payment processing)

definition: Digital marketplace platforms connecting buyers and sellers, facilitating payments between parties. Includes e-commerce marketplaces, sharing economy platforms, freelance platforms, crowdfunding platforms, and multi-vendor shopping platforms. Complex compliance environment as platform may act as merchant, facilitator, or payment intermediary.
pci_dss_definition: Per PCI DSS: Platform operator facilitating payment card transactions between multiple parties (buyers, sellers, service providers). May function as merchant of record, payment facilitator, or intermediary depending on payment model. Responsible for platform security, sub-merchant/seller compliance (if applicable), payment processing security, and protection of cardholder data. Compliance level typically Level 1 due to volume and complexity.
compliance_level: Typically Level 1 or 2 due to aggregated transaction volume
transaction_threshold: Typically exceeds 6 million transactions/year when aggregating all platform transactions
assessment_type: Annual Onsite Assessment by QSA (typically required); Report on Compliance; Quarterly ASV scans; Annual penetration testing
compliance_requirements: All 12 PCI DSS requirements for platform infrastructure; Platform application security (web application firewall, secure coding); API security (buyer/seller APIs); Payment gateway integration security; Tokenization (recommended); Sub-merchant compliance program (if payment facilitator model); Seller onboarding security validation; Know Your Customer (KYC) for sellers; Transaction monitoring and fraud detection; Split payment security (if revenue sharing); Multi-currency payment security; Chargeback management; Dispute resolution system security; Marketplace-specific fraud patterns; Identity verification; Seller agreement security clauses; Network segmentation; Logging and monitoring; Incident response; Quarterly ASV scans; Annual penetration testing; Third-party integration security (shipping, logistics, etc.)
applicable_standards: PCI DSS v4.0.1 (mandatory); ISO 27001; SOC 2 Type II; Payment facilitator regulations (if applicable); E-commerce regulations; GDPR; CCPA; Consumer protection laws; Marketplace-specific regulations; Anti-Money Laundering (AML); Know Your Customer (KYC); Regional e-commerce laws; Payment brand requirements; Platform security standards
